items.title: A CDC panel has struck down universal newborn hepatitis B vaccination
items.description: A reshaped vaccine committee voted to scale back newborn hepatitis B shots despite decades of data showing the birth dose is safe, effective and vital.
items.content: A reshaped vaccine committee voted to scale back newborn hepatitis B shots despite decades of data showing the birth dose is safe, effective and vital.

items.title: Big Neandertal noses weren’t made for cold
items.description: Tiny cameras threaded inside a Neandertal skull provide evidence that their big noses were not an adaptation to cold climates.
items.content: Tiny cameras threaded inside a Neandertal skull provide evidence that their big noses were not an adaptation to cold climates.

items.title: How male seahorses tap into their mothering side
items.description: By studying the genes responsible for the seahorse’s brood pouch, researchers uncovered a new route to “motherhood.”
items.content: By studying the genes responsible for the seahorse’s brood pouch, researchers uncovered a new route to “motherhood.”

items.title: Chatbots spewing facts, and falsehoods, can sway voters
items.description: Chatbots that dole out fact-laden arguments can sway voters. Those facts don’t have to be true.
items.content: Chatbots that dole out fact-laden arguments can sway voters. Those facts don’t have to be true.

items.title: How a bacterial toxin linked to colon cancer messes with DNA
items.description: A closeup look at colibactin’s structure reveals chemical motifs that guide its mutation-wreaking “warheads” to specific stretches of DNA.
items.content: A closeup look at colibactin’s structure reveals chemical motifs that guide its mutation-wreaking “warheads” to specific stretches of DNA.

items.title: Nanotyrannus is still not a teenage T. rex
items.description: Nanotyrannus wasn’t a juvenile T. rex but a petite adult of a separate species, a new study of fossil hyoid bones finds, bolstering a recent report.
items.content: Nanotyrannus wasn’t a juvenile T. rex but a petite adult of a separate species, a new study of fossil hyoid bones finds, bolstering a recent report.

items.title: A volcanic eruption might have helped bring the Black Plague to Europe
items.description: A volcanic eruption may have triggered a deadly chain of events that brought the Black Plague to Europe in the 14th century.
items.content: A volcanic eruption may have triggered a deadly chain of events that brought the Black Plague to Europe in the 14th century.

items.title: Ancient DNA reveals China’s first ‘pet’ cat wasn’t the house cat
items.description: The modern house cat reached China in the 8th century. Before that, another cat — the leopard cat — hunted the rodents in ancient Chinese settlements.
items.content: The modern house cat reached China in the 8th century. Before that, another cat — the leopard cat — hunted the rodents in ancient Chinese settlements.

items.title: Ancient southern Africans took genetic evolution in a new direction
items.description: An ancient, shared set of human-specific genes underwent changes in a geographically isolated population after around 300,000 years ago, scientists say.
items.content: An ancient, shared set of human-specific genes underwent changes in a geographically isolated population after around 300,000 years ago, scientists say.

items.title: Human-caused earthquakes are real. Here’s why even stable regions can snap
items.description: Human activity can cause “healed” faults to release their stored strength, triggering unexpected quakes in tectonically stable regions.
items.content: Human activity can cause “healed” faults to release their stored strength, triggering unexpected quakes in tectonically stable regions.

items.title: Twisted stacks of 2-D carbon act like a weird type of superconductor
items.description: “Magic-angle” graphene may provide new clues into poorly understood unconventional superconductors, which operate at higher-than-normal temperatures.
items.content: “Magic-angle” graphene may provide new clues into poorly understood unconventional superconductors, which operate at higher-than-normal temperatures.

items.title: Self-hypnosis with cooling mental imagery could ease hot flashes
items.description: Postmenopausal women who listened to self-guided hypnosis recordings daily for six weeks saw meaningful improvements in hot flash symptoms.
items.content: Postmenopausal women who listened to self-guided hypnosis recordings daily for six weeks saw meaningful improvements in hot flash symptoms.

items.title: Personalized ‘prehabilitation’ helps the body brace for major surgery
items.description: A small study finds that individualized prehab can dampen harmful immune responses and may reduce complications after an operation.
items.content: A small study finds that individualized prehab can dampen harmful immune responses and may reduce complications after an operation.

items.title: A therapeutic HPV vaccine shrank cervical tumors in mice
items.description: An HPV vaccine delivered into the nose can treat cervical tumors in mice. The vaccine targets a cancer protein produced by the virus.
items.content: An HPV vaccine delivered into the nose can treat cervical tumors in mice. The vaccine targets a cancer protein produced by the virus.

items.title: Canada just lost its measles elimination status. Is the U.S. next?
items.description: Canada has had more than a year of continuous measles transmission. The United States has until January to limit cases before losing status.
items.content: Canada has had more than a year of continuous measles transmission. The United States has until January to limit cases before losing status.

items.title: Here are 3 big ideas to combat climate change, with or without COP
items.description: As action from the U.N.’s huge COP30 international meeting falls short, smaller groups are banding together to find ways to fight climate change.
items.content: As action from the U.N.’s huge COP30 international meeting falls short, smaller groups are banding together to find ways to fight climate change.

items.title: A foot fossil suggests a second early human relative lived alongside Lucy
items.description: Foot bones and other fossils have been attributed to Australopithecus deyiremeda, a recently discovered species that may shake up the human family tree.
items.content: Foot bones and other fossils have been attributed to Australopithecus deyiremeda, a recently discovered species that may shake up the human family tree.

items.title: Listen to the crackle of Martian ‘mini-lightning’
items.description: A microphone on NASA’s Perseverance rover recorded the sounds of electrical discharges generated by dusty gusts.
items.content: A microphone on NASA’s Perseverance rover recorded the sounds of electrical discharges generated by dusty gusts.

items.title: Gratitude can increase joy, even if it feels a little cringe
items.description: Like exercise, gratitude takes many forms. Finding the right practice, research shows, is up to the individual.
items.content: Like exercise, gratitude takes many forms. Finding the right practice, research shows, is up to the individual.

items.title: Cuddly koalas had a brutal, blade-toothed close cousin
items.description: Ancient collagen preserved in the bones of extinct Australian mammals is revealing their evolutionary relationships, leading to some surprises.
items.content: Ancient collagen preserved in the bones of extinct Australian mammals is revealing their evolutionary relationships, leading to some surprises.
